{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3133833,"name":null,"username":"shush","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/aeb1de/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T20:08:09.099Z","cooked":"

Hello! This is the first year my team has a swerve drive, and we encountered two problems (which might be related): one, when driving in a completely straight line, it rotates a little on it’s own; and two, when we try to drive in a straight line while rotating, it goes in a big arc.

We don’t think it’s a code issue, because the problem persists with three entirely different codebases: our own code, SDS, and 364. It also persists with both field-relative and robot-relative driving.

We didn’t notice an obvious mechanical or electrical issue, but that might be just because we don’t know where to look.

Did anyone else have this problem, or do you know what might cause it? Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-25T20:12:47.183Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":917,"reads":348,"readers_count":347,"score":4654.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":424669,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51472,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating/424669/1","custom_user_title":"Programming","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3133854,"name":"Curt Rozeboom","username":"BlueEpiphone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blueepiphone/{size}/197122_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T20:26:17.653Z","cooked":"

Maybe someone with even more swerve experience than I will offer a different opinion, but I’d be checking the absolute encoder offsets to be sure they were correct, and then re-checking them. What types of encoders are you using and what type of gyro? If you let the robot sit and measure heading on these, do you see any drift? Otherwise, I’d say try swapping your absolute encoders or module positions and see if the problem changes with any swaps. That may help you identify an issue with one of them that isn’t immediately obvious? Just trying to think of what questions I’d be asking if I had this issue. Hope this helps!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-25T20:26:17.653Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":332,"readers_count":331,"score":91.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":424669,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating","display_username":"Curt Rozeboom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32089,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5010 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating/424669/2","custom_user_title":"5010 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3133865,"name":null,"username":"shush","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/aeb1de/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T20:43:38.693Z","cooked":"

We’re using a NavX for a gyro, and CANCoders for wheel angle. We redid the offsets multiple times, but only like one or two digits after the decimal, because more than that there’s just too much measurement noise.
The CANCoders are fairly new, and self-test good in the tuner.

What do you mean by “swapping module positions”?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-25T20:43:38.693Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":295,"readers_count":294,"score":109.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":424669,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":32089,"username":"BlueEpiphone","name":"Curt Rozeboom","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blueepiphone/{size}/197122_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51472,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating/424669/3","custom_user_title":"Programming","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3133871,"name":"Lyssia","username":"apotato","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/apotato/{size}/204534_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T20:49:29.916Z","cooked":"
Whitepaper: Swerve Drive Skew and Second Order Kinematics CD-Media: Papers
Team 449 made our first swerve drive a few months ago, and one of the first things we noticed is that when driving straight and spinning at the same time, the robot always skews in the direction of rotation. I’m sure many of you have also encountered this problem - if you’re wondering whether it’s happening because of an error in your code, the short answer is no. We spent a while trying to debug this issue, and through asking online we settled on the theory that since swerve constant translati…
","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-25T20:49:29.916Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":267,"readers_count":266,"score":123.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":424669,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating","display_username":"Lyssia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/whitepaper-swerve-drive-skew-and-second-order-kinematics/416964","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Whitepaper: Swerve Drive Skew and Second Order Kinematics","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52651,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8033 | Software Vice Captain"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating/424669/4","custom_user_title":"8033 | Software Vice Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3133872,"name":"Curt Rozeboom","username":"BlueEpiphone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blueepiphone/{size}/197122_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T20:51:37.855Z","cooked":"

Just literally changing which module is installed in each position, like swap your left and right front modules and see if the problem tracks, then the back. It’s a lot more work, though, so if there’s an easier way to spot the issue it’s probably worth it. We switched to a Pigeon instead of the NavX because they apparently drift a little more that they should, but what you’re describing sounds really bad, if it was that.

Ultimately, a swerve rotates because of the forces the wheels are exerting on the whole system, so one or more of them must be off of their expected mark by enough to create a rotational force.

You could try logging or visualizing the expected and actual absolute angles and looking for deviations.

If all those diagnostics look good, then I’d agree with apotato, you’re just experiencing the 2nd order problem.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-25T20:53:24.603Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":251,"readers_count":250,"score":95.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":424669,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating","display_username":"Curt Rozeboom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51472,"username":"shush","name":null,"avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/aeb1de/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32089,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5010 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating/424669/5","custom_user_title":"5010 Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3133882,"name":null,"username":"shush","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/aeb1de/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T20:57:01.764Z","cooked":"

Oh wow. This seems exactly like the problem we have, I’ll show it to the other programmers and we’ll see what we can do. Thank you so much!

I assume you’re using falcons since you were using 364lib. I spent a while trying to get this concept to work using 4481s code with 364lib and ran into some issues. If you guys end up pursuing it please let me know if you get it working so I can check my work against yours. If you’d like to see my code for it my teams GitHub is public and the code should be on the second-order-swerve branch of the charged-up repo
Link: GitHub - HighlanderRobotics/Charged-Up

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-25T21:01:58.241Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":218,"readers_count":217,"score":128.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":424669,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating","display_username":"Lyssia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/HighlanderRobotics/Charged-Up","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - HighlanderRobotics/Charged-Up","clicks":18}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51472,"username":"shush","name":null,"avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/aeb1de/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52651,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8033 | Software Vice Captain"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating/424669/7","custom_user_title":"8033 | Software Vice Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3133890,"name":"Philip Leal","username":"philleal","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/c67d28/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T21:05:17.060Z","cooked":"

Sounds like you are describing a similar problem that we were having. In testing, we found that if we pull the the rotation from the gyro instead of pulling from the drivetrain in our DriveCommand.execute() method that feeds into the ChassisSpeeds.fromFieldRelativeSpeeds() method, it fixed our problem.

We still need to fix futher down in the code so that it can pull from drivetrain.

We based our swerve drive code directly from SDS.

Hope this helps!

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-25T21:19:06.216Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":52.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424669,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating","display_username":"Lyssia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51472,"username":"shush","name":null,"avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/aeb1de/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52651,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8033 | Software Vice Captain"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-goes-in-an-arc-while-rotating/424669/11","custom_user_title":"8033 | Software Vice Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3134074,"name":"SndMndBdy","username":"SndMndBdy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/13edae/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-26T01:33:28.290Z","cooked":"

It’s possible that your code is rotating you about a point which is not in the center of your robot because you have the coordinate system of your wheels relative to the center of rotation incorrect. It is similar to the problem that is described in this thread:

Weird Swerve Allignment Problem Programming
My team’s been building a swervedrive during the offseason and we’re having trouble figuring out the wheel alignment. We’re able to drive the robot in the robot oriented way perfectly (meaning no on-place rotation, just movement up-down-left-right). The wheels align when we do that. When we try to make the robot rotate in place, two of the wheels go in one direction, and the other two go in the other. My code is similar to this one: What can I do to make both swivelling and normal driving wor…

I don’t think that’s the problem since it rotates around the center when I just rotate it. The problem I’ve found is that at high speeds the rotation feedforward on some of the swerve modules becomes extremely high causing the module to spin in place.
